audio_caption: The audio begins with somber piano music. Then, a male speaker welcomes listeners to the 2022 Antigua Forum. He states the forum is hosted by the University of Francisco Marroquin and introduces his guest, a Brazilian journalist, political scientist, and politician named Marcel van Hattum. He mentions that his guest is a member of the Chamber of Deputies and the Vice Leader of a political party. The male speaker then says "welcome Marcel" to which the guest responds in a more subdued tone expressing pleasure to be there.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing his pleasure at being present. He then addresses another male speaker, identifying him as "Marcel," and acknowledging his early election to a city council at age 18, and subsequent service in the Brazilian Congress. In a conversational tone, he asks Marcel about the reasons he initially ran for public office and continues his service today.

The audio features one male speaker who says his parents thought he was "crazy or something" for getting into politics since they were not involved; his father was a civil engineer, his mother an architect and small entrepreneur. He felt, even at a young age, it was vital to have people "fight the state bureaucracy," so he affiliated himself with a political party. It is a necessity in Brazil to be affiliated to become a member and run, and he ran for city council. He was a journalist covering the city council and thought he could collaborate with his community. The speaker then recounts his journey from city council to Congress.

The audio clip features a single male speaker recounting his political journey. He mentions serving on the council and running for state legislature twice, changing course again in 2013 due to protests and encouragement from friends and supporters. He describes a positive outcome, winning by "only 351 votes." His tone is conversational and reflective.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing his political career. He mentions running for the federal house with a "partido novo" party, emphasizing it was a deliberate choice for a small, libertarian party focused on free markets and individual rights. Despite this, he recounts receiving 350,000 votes, becoming the most voted candidate in his state. The speaker reflects on this journey, calling it "quite a journey."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker beginning to describe his journey. He then says, "in addition to that, I understand you started your career" as a newspaper delivery man and a reporter for a Brazilian newspaper. He inquires why the person got involved in these roles and asks about their view on the role of a free press.

The audio features one male speaker reflecting on his first job outside of family employment. He fondly recalls delivering newspapers and interacting with people, expressing happiness with this experience and enjoying such interactions.

A male speaker starts by describing a time when he was 16 and went to the United States for a robotics competition. He told the newspaper owner that he was going to the US and would send text about the "American Way of Life". The owner accepted the idea, and he sent the text voluntarily. After he returned, the owner hired him as a reporter for the local newspaper because "everybody liked the text".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker emphasizing the importance of a free press for democracy. He asserts his advocacy for free press, freedom of expression, and the importance of neutrality in reporting, especially in stories. He believes journalists should prioritize truth, even if it's unfavorable. The clip ends with a single burst of static.

The clip begins with a male speaker transitioning into discussing writing. He mentions the listener is the author of two books and asks about their subject matter and the reception of their message. This speaker has a conversational tone. A second speaker, presumably the author, responds affirmatively.

The audio begins with one male speaker discussing his first book, which is a collection of speeches he gave in the state legislature. He describes it as a legacy, a humble one, which allows people to read about his biography and the authors he likes, including Mises, Bastiat, Friedman, and other classical liberal and libertarian thinkers. His tone is reflective and somewhat formal.

The clip starts with a male speaker announcing the release of his second book, written in partnership with Tiago Albers, a theologian. Both authors are Lutherans. The speaker mentions the first book's title, "Somos Nos con uma Voz," translating to "This is us with one voice," and connects it to expressing others' opinions, specifically those he represented during his state legislature term. He then introduces his second book with a provocative title, "Is Politics a Devil's Thing?" He explains it tries to put in perspective how politics has been played since biblical and ancient times through Christianity's history, and what is the importance of politics in today's Christian life.

The clip opens with a male speaker referencing speeches given in Congress and the legislature, and asking about Brazil, quoting, "I don't want to live in another country. I want to live in another Brazil." He inquires about Brazil's trajectory and potential solutions. A second male speaker responds, mentioning that the speech was given at the state legislature in Rio Grande do Sul. He notes the speech's impact and relates that he wants to live in another Brazil. He also stated the bottom line of his speech. He states that giving people more freedom and limiting the state are crucial steps. There is then an acknowledgment by a male speaker, followed by background speech.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker expressing hope to see someone in the future, thanking someone named Francisco, and congratulating others for their work. He then says he hopes to see them next year. The clip then transitions to music, featuring a soft piano melody that evokes a peaceful mood.
